comments.commentBody:
"Had it been asked out of the blue or based on innuendo, I'd be among those hollering that it was out of bounds."

"But context does matter, which is why I held my opinion in reserve until we learned more."

http://fifthdown.blogs.nytimes.com...

You defended Ireland immediately following the first reports of this, before any claims about the context were made. If you felt these unverified claims regarding the context of the question validated your initial defense of Ireland, then say that, but don't say you withheld opinion when the comments on the article linked to above to say otherwise.

Atte,

Millen knows more about the NFL than you or I do.

And please read the part where Bryant offered the information that his Dad was a pimp and his Mom worked for his Dad.

Bakes,

Here's what I am claiming:

You jumped the gun.

Don't feel bad, so did most of America, including lots of people more famous than either of us.

Luis,

These are not job interviews.

That's what people seem to keep forgetting. Most of those who object to these sorts of questions have used the argument that you wouldn't get asked that question in a job interview.

These are background discussions, feeling-out sessions. These are men who are lining up for massive payday without having been on the field for a single NFL snap.

These are men who, too often, bring baggage with them. Certainly we applaud those who overcome their baggage, but let's please be honest: If you have a world of talent (YES, GOD-GIVEN), almost anything about you will be overlooked by those who want to leverage that talent for their own aims. You ARE a commodity and you ACCEPT those terms, because you want the BIG PAYDAY.

So now you're in this room talking to a man who has to decide if he is going to make you rich, without ever having seen you play as a pro. Now your entitled life comes face to face with a world of zero excuses and zero acceptance of failure. Now you are face to face with the top level, men as talented as you and maybe more. Now is when the free ride ends.

And as we have clearly learned, these men are not always ready for that transition. So much money - why drive drunk? So much money - why carry a gun? So much money - why consort with drug dealers and prostitutes? So much money - why kill dogs?

I understand that it's distasteful, but are we infants here? We can tolerate distasteful. We do it every day. Some stuff just has to be done, and we don't have to like it.

Is the argument that the pampering must continue? Haven't we all at one time or another railed against pampering?

I have little use for the argument that players are being disrespected by tough questions. (a) So what? Is disrespect a crime? A GM has to report to his owner whether or not this man deserves guaranteed millions. He should worry that a question may make the player feel disrespected? So, no questions which might hurt the young man's feelings? This cannot be a serious argument. (b) What is disrespectful about exploring the man's background? If the very act of doing so is on its face disrespectful, then you tie a team's hands behind its back. Now, due diligence is disrespect? We turn the process on its head?

And again, why? To sustain the sense of entitlement? To keep playing the "don't know don't tell" game so we can have this commodity on our team?

And of course that used to be the case. Turn a blind eye and all that. And then one player after another embarrassed the league, his team, himself and his family. And suddenly "character" became, for many teams, the most important asset of a player.

And that is each team's choice. Perhaps Ireland should have simply declined to interview Bryant, or perhaps Ireland wanted to know more about the man and how he had overcome his baggage. I don't know and nobody else knows what it takes to get a feeling about the maturation process of another person. The best any of us can do is try to get to know some things about the person and see how we feel about it.

It is an unavoidably imperfect process, and we're all just doing the best we can. I'm sure that Bryant was upset by the question, but let's be brutally honest: He's more upset that his Dad was a pimp and his Mom was a drug dealer.

Paul,

It was a perfectly natural question under the circumstances, perfectly natural.

There must be a blue moon. I agree with Friedman.

The President is still hanging back, assessing his options. Lindsey Graham is still in hissy-fit mode, the better placate the South Carolina tea party, I suppose. (In fact, the Graham snit makes it disingenuous for Friedman to posit there is one Senate Republican behind energy reform legislation, because Graham was that lone Senator.)

But there are surprising signs of light elsewhere. Graham Amigo Joe Lieberman just "opened the door to trying to advance Senate climate legislation without the backing of...Graham," according to The Hill. And Harry Reid, who is occasionally a profile in courage, was more forthcoming than the President today. Reid said, "I think we're all going to back off from offshore drilling until we get a better handle of how we can make it safe."

I'm hoping the President can learn from Republican Arnold Schwarzenegger, who yesterday was unequivocally courageous when he rescinded his support of limited drilling off the California Coast. California is famously strapped for cash, but Schwarzenegger had the guts to say he'd find another place to raise the huge revenues offshore drilling promised to funnel into his state's coffers. "You turn on the television and see this enormous disaster, you say to yourself, 'Why would we want to take on that kind of risk?'" the Governator asks. Why, indeed?

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

..."Responding to this oil spill could well become the most important leadership test of the Obama presidency. The president has always had the right instincts on energy, but he is going to have to decide just how much he wants to rise to this occasion — whether to generate just an emergency response that over months ends the spill or a systemic response that over time ends our addiction. Needless to say, it would be a lot easier for the president to lead if more than one Republican in the Senate was ready to lift a finger to help him."

Aye, and therein lies the rub! I for once do agree with you, Tom, which is a rare delight! However, I do not hold any hope that the Republicans will grow up, come to their senses and stop playing Nintendo! They are much too invested in their adolescent rebellion and naysaying against anything Obama supports! And so far, unfortunately, the polls seem to support them. How crazy is that?

I think it is going to take an all out truth squad, armed with the facts--accurately reported by the media. This includes somebody besides Keith Olbermann calling out Fox News! People need to have the unpleasant, horrible, getting worse facts in their faces EVERY DAY! No sound bites or partisan bickering. Just the facts. How many birds have died today. Exactly where the oil spill has moved. How many jobs lost today. How many sea creatures washed up on beaches. And PICTURES!

Are we mature enough as a country to do this? Can our people move beyond "Drill Baby Drill" to "Save our Ecological Soul?"

I have an idea.... Instead of worrying about Green Jobs and Obama "never letting a crisis go to waste" to pass another bill we can't afford to pay for. Why doesn't Obama create the jobs that the stimulus bill was supposed to create?

I understand your commitment to a green economy, but remember -- every drop of oil _conserved_ is a drop of oil we don't need to drill for, or support with our military in the Middle East.

Please put conservation at the very top of your list when encouraging investment in our country's energy future.

You are naiive , Tom.  Under Obama, the too-big-to-fail banks have grown even bigger.  Rest assured, that Big Oil will grow as well under Obama.  Expect the same for Big Ag, Big Insurance, Big Pharma, etc.

President Bush was handed a national tragedy to galvanize the nation behind a war he was already planning.

As you mentioned, President Obama has a similar opportunity. But will our often too-calm, above-all-that president find it beneath him to make lemonade with this lemon?

I hope not, lest we find ourselves a generation from now still invading other nations to ensure we get our daily fix.

Funny to see the same people in Southern states who rail against big government now begging for help from Obama to fight a corporate disaster caused by their own support of offshore drilling.

http://akwag.blogspot.com...

It begins to look as though the planet was doomed from the moment the automobile-assembly-line was perfected. Our affordable-boxes-on-wheels have become ESSENTIAL - not just to get us from place to place (mostly one at a time) but to reassure us that we are in charge. It is a deeply-rooted conviction that will not be denied; and it may yet kill us off.

If Obama and our Congress cannot get the message after this disaster and get a meaningful climate/energy bill then I'm writing them off and giving up all hope with our Federal Government.

The fierce urgency of now. Truly.

For our children, and our children's children.

Sorry, Tom, but I just don't see where this "clean energy" movement is going to come from. Breaking our addiction to oil is going to require that Americans give up their fast, high-powered autos and embrace slower, lighter, low-powered vehicles (mostly powered by electricity), and also embrace public transit. Americans love their fast cars and SUVs, and will never give them up.
